div.p:
[LibNote]30[/LibNote] Bowood Tuesday Sep[superscript]r[/superscript]. 8th. - we arrived here yes- terday to dinner & were most cordially received - no one here but M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Dumont - a young French [underline]judge[/underline] - and Sir George Paul - gone both this morning - no company expected for some days - Your letter to Honora of the 3[superscript]d[/superscript]. Sep reached us just as we were getting into the carriage to come here - But yours & Lovells which you mention as having sent by M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Lees's frank has not yet reached us - and most anxious we are to receive it - The mo ment I receive it I will write
I now merely write this time in utmost haste to say we are at last where you, kindest of friends, have so much wished us to be - Honora is well & tho thin looked extremely pretty & nice yesterday at dinner - Miss Wilkinson & Miss Briscoe have done all you could have wished for her - Lady Lansdowne is very kind in her man- ner towards her - I think Lady L just the same per -son - only fatter & more formed in manner. This place as far as I can judge not naturally hand some - the house magnifi cent - Our rooms opening one into another just what
[LibNote]31[/LibNote] you would wish for us - George lodged near us - He is well & I believe happy - and desires poor Molly sh[superscript]d[/superscript]. be told he is well. I send this note through M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Ward - and send many letters as the shortest me- thod of communicating many things to you which I literally have not time to copy - I have just written to my Aunt R. the first letter since one from Bangor, - I have copied [underline]for[/underline] her from Dumonts letter all that relates to the M[superscript]s[/superscript]. - I long to rest my mind by going to my [underline]work[/underline] again - What a contrast between all [deletion]the [unclear][/unclear][/deletion] round us at this moment and all at
home -! I [underline]endeavor[/underline] dear mother to hope that this sleep so sound & often repeated will restore him - But a secret feeling at the bottom of my mind arising I believe from Cramp ton's predictions & [underline]his[/underline] likeness to Henry make me tremble - I agree with you that if he does not recover it will be better to place him in Eng- land than any where in land than anywhere in Ireland - the worst place in the world for the reasons you mention would be M[superscript]r[/superscript]. Fox's -
div.closer: I am called away affec[superscript]y[/superscript]. y[superscript]r[/superscript]. Maria E

postscript.p: I find that [deletion]mem[/deletion] Lord & Lady Grenville are to be here tomorrow. I must answer that I cannot recommend a governess - for I dont know of a good one - [underline]do you?[/underline] - [underline]answer[/underline] this Maria Sept[superscript]r[/superscript]. 1818
